H0.text: Low vapor pressure is the property of water that allows it to retain the energy needed to power a hurricane.

H1.text: High specific heat is the property of water that allows it to retain the energy needed to power hurricanes, which are driven by the energy they get from ocean water.

H2.text: High surface tension is the property of water that allows it to retain the energy needed to power hurricanes, which are driven by the energy they get from ocean water.

H3.text: Low freezing point is the property of water that allows it to retain the energy needed to power a hurricane, because hurricanes are driven by the energy they get from ocean water.

A4.text: Liquid water has one of the highest specific heat capacities among common substances, about 4184 J⋅kg−1⋅K−1 at 20 °C.

A5.text: The specific heat capacities of iron, granite, and hydrogen gas are about 449 J⋅kg−1⋅K−1, 790 J⋅kg−1⋅K−1, and 14300 J⋅kg−1⋅K−1, respectively.
